text: baby boo-boo
hi everyone Anthony Fantana here
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new Phoenix LP
bankrupt Phoenix is a French pop and
rock outfit who has been around a lot
longer than some people assume mostly
due to their very recent spike in
popularity with their fourth full-length
album Wolfgang Amadeus Phoenix in 2009
an album that made the band a bit of an
overnight sensation going gold in
America Canada as well as Australia
which is absolutely no surprise
whatsoever considering how many
sharp-ass singles are on this LP 1901
Armistice Lisztomania and lasso this
album was filled with catchy sweet
quirky memorable guitars really bouncy
synthesizers some very agreeable vocals
and overall just a really poppy sound I
did like quite a few tracks on Wolfgang
Amadeus Fenix but I've never really been
a big Phoenix fan to be completely
honest the band's sound to me has always
reflected sort of a loss in personality
within the genres of indie pop and indie
rock over the years but it's not like
there's any reason to hold negative
feelings toward the band and it's not
like the band came out with this fourth
album changed their sound and sold out
the band's music has always been really
sort of sweet and hook heavy it's just
like Phoenix had the right idea the
whole time and had foresight and I
commend them for doing that and also
making music that they want to make
still I have to kind of raise an eyebrow
when it comes to people who were big
fans of maybe the band's past few LPS
and are giving a listen to this new LP
and are a little disappointed with
bankrupts lack of surprises I wonder
when his Phoenix ever really been about
surprises at all their discography
they're a musical trajectory has been
over the course of their career
incredibly safe about as safe as taking
a swim in a puddle with a snorkel and
water wings as far as indie rock and pop
go
Phoenix's music has incredibly standard
there's not an angle that you can look
at it in which it does look standard you
can't even call the band obnoxious or
overly romantic in the way that you
would Vampire Weekend or over
loan in the way that you would say
Arcade Fire is sometimes or even too
sweet and saccharine in the way that man
Kim or even Passion Pit can be the
band's vocals consistently just don't
really stick out to me with any sort of
flair if anything they remind me of like
of Montreal's Kevin Barnes if he had
never had his heart broken or if he had
never heard a David Bowie record all
these issues aside Phoenix does bring a
notable change on this new album and
that change is an increase in
synthesizers and electronics guitar
still has a real presence on these
tracks but these synthesizers they're
really turned up to make the overall
feel of this record thicker and bright a
drum machine occasionally pops up on
this album and there are a lot of
grooves whether it be in the hook or the
verses on these pop tunes that feel like
they're ripped straight from old 80s new
wave b-sides who we couldn't even find
on Google if we could remember their
names
the band's approach on this LP is far
from original these guys are not the
first to rock grooves like this they
won't be the last but still sharp
songwriting does stick out like the song
entertainment opening this LP up really
driving groove on this LP and it starts
out with this killer burning synth
melody B nee nee nee nee nee nee nee nee
nee nee nee nee me me me the vocals come
off pretty emotive on the verse with a
nice down stroke guitar in there it's
really good tune and the song trying to
be cool the song has a sticky melody and
this groove that feels like it's a
bridge between funk disco and 80s new
wave the song is so good I totally
suggest it as this album's next single
because it's definitely more
entertaining than this albums other
single chloroformed which has all these
dinky drum machines that just don't do
anything for the track are very
redundant and almost pointless cyntha
melody that copies exactly what the
vocals do and this weak gutless piano
phrase that feels like it's just a
direct copy of the pianos from Elton
John's Bennie in the Jets
it's a really lackluster tune in my
opinion and one of a good handful of
moments on this album where the band is
really mucking up their sound mucking up
these tunes with just too many elements
to the point where the songs just really
lose their pop their snap
they're instantaneousness in translation
like the song SOS and bel-air which not
only hits the listener with many pieces
within a short span of time but all of
these pieces are layered so heavily with
numerous ideas flying around into this
jumbled whirlwind there are some sweet
melodies that are in this tune and
others on here but they feel that
they're canceled out by a hundred other
ideas competing with them like on the
song Drakkar Noir or the very drum
machine driven tune don't or the track
oblique City these Tunes are a little
more clear than the track SOS and
bel-air but still not many songs on this
album come off as meticulously crafted
as tunes on Wolfgang Amadeus Phoenix as
almost as if the band had the approach
of just sort of throwing everything at
the wall and just sort of seeing what
sticks there are some other songs on
here though that are interesting take me
by surprise like the song bourgeois
which is very 80s 80s
esque slow jams very easygoing it's got
a sweet melody sensual vocals on the
track it's a killer and the title track
surprisingly enough is is nearly a
seven-minute synth Odyssey with a vocal
part on the back end which is actually
incredibly entertaining the band did a
great job of crafting some sounds on
this thing overall I have to say this
album wasn't terrible but it wasn't
great either it's really sort of middle
of the road for me mostly because of how
spotty it is there's some sharp songs on
here backed up against some very jumbled
songs as well a lot of tracks here
pretty much for the whole album the band
is rocking this just nearly dead
deathbed 80 chic revivalism that they
don't exactly make feel fresh and even
though I did like some of the tunes on
here I still can't help but feel that
when I listen to a Phoenix tune there is
something there whether it be the vocals
the way the band plays are instruments
there's just some sort of lack of
character there to be completely honest
I'm feeling a decent strong five on this
thing if you've given it a listen
what did you think of it did you love it
hate it why what do you think I should
review next and that's it
Anthony Fantana Phoenix forever
[Music]
